projectText:
Between 1953 and 1983 a radio amateur in the region of Avila received in his mailbox more than 6,400 QSL postcards, confirming the radio contact established with senders from more than 70 countries around the world.
From Leningrad to Louisiana, from Beirut to Buenos Aires, from Cuenca to Kyoto, Alfredo Abella (Ávila,1923-1992) obtained thousands of representations of the world printed on 10x15cm cards. QSLs reflect the efforts to synthesize and translate identities and contexts at a time when international communication between individuals was a challenge and an exception. 
Understood as a physical confirmation of a listening between different stations, each QSL received represented a radio conversation in which data was exchanged to be transmitted. 
 
In a pre-internet era (from 1950 to 1992), ham radio, through its materialization in QSL, gave the opportunity to extend the gaze across remote landscapes and distant iconographies. Drawn into a competition to cover distances, this amateur radio took another name, diexism. Diexism, defined by wikipedia, is the hobby of listening to distant or exotic radio stations.
 
In 1991, Alfredo (EA1EG) managed to establish contact with ZL2AJR, located 35km from Levin (New Zealand), the antipodes of Avila, the furthest point on the globe.
The postcard, apart from describing the information needed to confirm the contact, included representations of the location of the sender. In the upper right hand corner, a green engraving represented a Hei-tiki , a sacred figure of the Maori people. EA1EG heard the voice of ZL2AJR, but could not see the figure Hei-tiki on the QSL postcard that arrived in her mailbox.* Handling a discarded Civil War grenade, Alfredo lost his sight in 1944.
 
His love of radio emerged, as it does for many other visually impaired people, as an accessible and emancipatory alternative for leisure and socialization. Forty years later, Alfredo founded the Asociación de Radioaficionados Invidentes de ESpaña (ARIES), the Spanish Association of Blind Radio Amateurs, where visually impaired people meet to this day.
 
The collection of postcards remained stored in an attic until 2017, when Alfredo's family systematized the archive and scanned for two years front and back of the 6877 postcards in the collection.
This web page presents all these images, geolocated and chronologically ordered, in the form of an atlas and timeline of the extensive territory that Alfredo Abella travelled along from his station on Paseo Dos de Mayo in Avila.
 
Conventional archives tend to be defined through the quantitative accumulation of elements ascribed to a specific order. They rarely transform their structures. Unlike this model of archival practice and preservation, productive archives seek to offer an open framework, which allows the production of new relationships. This project aims to generate a new framework in which the archive becomes a potential element, a starting point for new narratives and creative processes that revert to the archive itself.
 
If you would like to collaborate with the project or make an inquiry, please write to hola@vendedoresdehumo.com
 
EA1EG is possible thanks to the support of Carmen Santacana, but also to the institutional support of A.R.I.E.S. (Asociación de Radioaficionados Invidentes ESpañoles), U.R.E. (Unión de Radioaficionados Españoles), Archivo Histórico Provincial de Ávila, O.N.C.E.
